body:
Sounds good. Just make sure you can do the refactor without changing the
interface.
Think carefully when creating Interface s since it's very hard to change
later

On Nov 26, 2016 7:08 AM, "Xingjian Shi" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @piiswrong <https://github.com/piiswrong> I've removed the python wrapper
> of topk. However I think the wrapper for arange could be kept currently.
> How about keeping it this way and refactor in the future?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3952#issuecomment-263068176>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAiudMhs625khJ4-nevD6lYk1q6wt571ks5rCEtsgaJpZM4K6lcJ>
> .
>

I am sorry to make you misunderstand, I am not saying benchmarking mnist. I just want to know, is there a way to add your benchmark without affecting the normal use of train_mnist.py.

When running train_mnist.py, an error occurs:

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "train_mnist.py", line 161, in <module>
>     train_model.fit(args, net, get_iterator(data_shape))
>   File "C:\Users\Chason\Downloads\mxnet-master\example\image-classification\train_model.py", line 92, in fit
>     if args.benchmark:
> AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'benchmark'
@mli @piiswrong  Anyone can help to merge the code? Or if there is any problem, Pls let me know, I'm willing to change it
@KeyKy Not yet, but problem was located to bn in networks!

Some notes:

1. Since, as you mention in the README, this is built on example/nce-loss, I think it would be better to just extend nce-loss to run the original or yours optionally, to reduce code duplication and make the examples maintainable -- then we won't end up with two nce-loss examples and directories with a lot of the same code.

2. DMLC keeps their binaries for mxnet.io in https://github.com/dmlc/web-data -- if you'd like to write up a tutorial in markdown, you could put them there. Otherwise, it would be better to just link to wherever they're hosted rather than keep them in this repo.

3. It would be nice to have pydocs for these -- I know the original didn't have pydocs, but since you're familiar with it and are currently working on it, it would be great if the original code were documented as well.

Please move the images to web-data.
Also consider @andremoeller 's comment. If you don't want to work on it now we can merge in this and refactor later.

I met the same problem as in the 3rd post, but not sure if my solution applies here. I'm on Ubuntu 16.04 with CUDA 8 and CUDNN v5.1.
```
❯ python train_mnist.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train_mnist.py", line 1, in <module>
    import find_mxnet
  File "/mnt/raid/user1/Temp/image-classification/find_mxnet.py", line 2, in <module>
    import mxnet as mx
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from .base import MXNetError
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/base.py", line 43, in <module>
    _LIB = _load_lib()
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/base.py", line 35, in _load_lib
    lib = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(lib_path[0])
  File "/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 440, in LoadLibrary
    return self._dlltype(name)
  File "/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 362, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: /home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/bin/../lib/libgomp.so.1: version `GOMP_4.0' not found (required by /home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/../../lib/libmxnet.so)
```

Then I realised that it's looking at a different place for `libgomp.so.1` from what 
```ldd ~/mxnet/lib/libmxnet.so``` 
says:
```
❯ ldd lib/libmxnet.so | grep libgomp
	libgomp.so.1 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgomp.so.1 (0x00007f3e30635000)
```

Turns out that those are all just symbolic links to the actual library file `libgomp.so.1.0.0`

so I replaced `/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/bin/../lib/libgomp.so.1.0.0` with `/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgomp.so.1.0.0` and it proceeded to the next error:
```
❯ python train_mnist.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train_mnist.py", line 1, in <module>
    import find_mxnet
  File "/mnt/user1/rluo/Temp/image-classification/find_mxnet.py", line 2, in <module>
    import mxnet as mx
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from .base import MXNetError
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/base.py", line 43, in <module>
    _LIB = _load_lib()
  File "/home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/base.py", line 35, in _load_lib
    lib = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(lib_path[0])
  File "/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 440, in LoadLibrary
    return self._dlltype(name)
  File "/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 362, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: /home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/bin/../lib/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.20' not found (required by /home/user1/mxnet/python/mxnet/../../lib/libmxnet.so)
```

from here I started to suspect that it's all `anaconda`'s fault...

```ldd ~/mxnet/lib/libmxnet.so``` 
returns 
```
❯ ldd lib/libmxnet.so | grep libstdc++
	libstdc++.so.6 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007fadd0a21000)
```

`/home/user1/anaconda3/envs/mxnet/bin/../lib/libstdc++.so.6` linkes to `libstdc++.so.6.0.19`, while `/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6` links to `libstdc++.so.6.0.21`

So I copied `libstdc++.so.6.0.21` over and changed the symbolic links, and it seems to work fine now.
Thanks for posting the solution! I met the exact same problem and your solution worked for me.
Currently custom ops are not tested. I'm worried this might break it. Have you tested examples/numpy-ops/custom_softmax.py?

This PR only includes some syntax changes in `include/c_api.h` for compatibility reason. I am working on Haskell interface of MXNet via CFFI and these flaws are treated as syntax error by C compiler.

I also think test cases for custom ops are necessary but this problem should be solved by another separated patch. This PR only intends to make C API header files available for pure C compiler. This patch doesn't affect the semantics of original code, as well as the structures of `struct CustomOpInfo` and `struct CustomOpPropInfo`.

I'm going to strip tensorboard for logging and visualization as mentioned in #3306 and have started working on it. It's my pleasure to learn from you guys and I think your suggestions are helpful.
Besides, I have noticed that there are active changes related to C API in the nnvm branch, is there any roadmap about merging nnvm to main branch?

We won't migrate to py3 but will try to keep python 2/3 compatibility.
You are welcome to submit a PR to make it compatible with python 2 and 3.

Otherwise, we'll try to find someone to fix it.

My point is these changes will break customops. Have you verified that they won't?
nnvm will be merged in a few weeks. If you are sensitive to api change I recommend you use NNVM branch

This looks good to me.
Should we fix the prototypes for custom ops in python side?
Yes, we'd better do that. In most conventions, it won't hurt anyway, because bool is passed via integer in C ABI.
As long we do not have array of bools(or pointer of bool) it is fine, and the ABI should remain compatible. but a better practice would be use int instead of bool

@piiswrong   main scripts are as follows:
train_data = np.load('X_train.npy')
val_data = np.load('X_val.npy')
train_label = np.load('Y_train.npy')
val_label = np.load('Y_val.npy')
print train_data.shape
print val_data.shape
train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data=train_data, label=train_label,batch_size=batch_size,shuffle=True)
val_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data=val_data, label=val_label,batch_size=batch_size)
model.fit(
      X                  = train_iter,
     eval_data          = val_iter,
     eval_metric        = ['accuracy'],
     batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size,5),
     epoch_end_callback = checkpoint
     )

@leopd @mli

The way tensorboard works is it takes in a log file printed in a specific format and then renders them.
So we don't necessarily need tf.scalar_summary and tf.session to use it. We simply need to print log in the same format and run tensorboard.

Here is what I think would be a ideal solution:
1. we strip a minimum set of files related to tensorboard out of tensorflow and build it with Makefile or cmake, not bazel.
2. we modify mxnet's logging format so that it conforms with tensorboard.

But I haven't looked into this in-depth so this might be hard/impossible. So feel free to do anything that works for you first. We can discuss whether we want to merge it into mxnet or provide it as a separate solution afterwards.

It's the same with caffe's SoftmaxWithLoss.
We do need to improve the docs.

because by default cpu ops are not multi threaded. Use USE_MKLDNN=1 in config.mk if you want fast cpu performance.

Grabbing all cpu and gpu resources on startup is very unfriendly to other applications. Also most people care more about gpu performance and multithreaded cpu ops actually hurt compete with gpu scheduling thread and hurt performance.

Looks like you are using inception?
Please use latest mxnet code and updated symbols from data.mxnet.io/models

You need to modify c++ code for this. See cudnn_off option in src/operators/convolution-inl.h
You can add this option to bn layer

I think this PR is good. I can remove the python wrapper of arange in ndarray.py now. However, I still have some problems directly using `mx.sym.arange`. Sometimes I want it to be
```python
a = mx.sym.arange(10, dtype=float)
```
which should be equivalent to 
```python
a = mx.nd.arange(10, dtype=float)
```
But there are checks https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/python/mxnet/cython/symbol.pyx#L137-L139, https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/python/mxnet/_ctypes/symbol.py#L60-L65 that disable this behavior.
I don't think dtype=float should be allowed. Its ambiguous. Should it mean float32 or 64?
@precedenceguo does custom operator work in python3?

@piiswrong The problem is that the current API do not allow missing keys when setting arguments.
The following is allowed in the current setting:
```python
a = mx.sym.sum(start=10, dtype=np.float32)
```
The following is not allowed (start is missing):
```python
a = mx.sym.arange(10, dtype=np.float32)
```
Another example
Valid:
```python
a = mx.sym.Variable('a')
b = mx.sym.sum(a, axis=1)

a = mx.nd.ones((10, 10))
b = mx.nd.sum(a, axis=1)
b = mx.nd.sum(a, 1)
```
Invalid:
```python
a = mx.sym.Variable('a')
b = mx.sym.sum(a, 1)
```
@tqchen Could you have a look?
Current API in general do not support positional argument that is non symbolic
ndarray api actually supports it.

Yea, I fixed this one by downloading those files. However, I got another problem. I am not sure how to refill these two parameters. fcnxs_model_prefix = "model_pascal/FCN32s_VGG16" and flist_name = "train.lst"

Hi @ameshkoff, the variable `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` is for Linux, not windows. In my experience with precompiled versions, one source of problems is that you might not be using the same external libraries version as the person who compiled the original (i.e. same CUDA version). Also, please note that in the [precompiled](https://github.com/yajiedesign/mxnet/releases/tag/20161125) there is not `3rdparty` folder, while in the official mxnet release there is.
I would try to do a symbolic link to `libhdfs.so` and `libhdfs.so.0`. Also I would make sure that the library is in the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`.

from .rpn import proposal, proposal_target

My memory of using tensorboard is that those logfiles quickly get extremely large.  Do people really share those logfiles with each other?  It also made me worry that the huge amount of I/O would limit performance -- which would be more of an issue with MXNet than TF.  So that's something else we can experiment/measure: what kind of IO bandwidth would be needed to produce these logfiles.
you can change that to BatchNorm
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/src/executor/graph_executor.cc#L103
you do not need to pass the shape and dtype into _zeros, they should be able to get automatically inferred
thanks. but already fixed in #3999
Actually the search function has already been built in the index page. We only need to adjust the css to make it look nice.

+1 for runtime shape inference symbol.
Creating such kind of symbol is easy, however, current Ops must change behaviors according to "shape" or "axis", etc. More specifically, Ops that take "shape-like" parameters must take into consideration more inputs including symbolic shape.

I was thinking about something like:
```
shape = mx.symbol.SymbolicShape(data=data)
a = mx.symbol.Variable(name="xxx", symbolic_shape=shape)
b = mx.symbol.SliceChannel(symbolic_num_outputs=shape[1])
```

Variable, Crop, ROIPooling, Reshape, SliceChannel, SpatialTransformer, broadcast_axis, broadcast_to, expand_dims, normal, slice_axis, sum, sum_axis, uniform.
Roughly there are 10+ Ops to be affected. So it's not a simple task.
example/warpctc  @sosong   You need to use an old version of warpctc from https://github.com/baidu-research/warp-ctc with version 5bfb46e83bcb338a09fbf875cb0b02bc39746b36

This is not yet possible because the shape inference is done during graph initialization time, instead of runtime to give better memory planning. We might include alternative executor later, to support dynamic runtime shaping. But there is always a tradeoff between what is provided vs what can be optimized
@zlmzju  thanks , i have upload it to http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/data/
